newsitem.title: USA: U.S. economy still expanding but shows some weakness.
newsitem.headline: U.S. economy still expanding but shows some weakness.

text.p: The economy kept growing in May and early June though "pockets" of weakness" appeared, the Federal Reserve said Wednesday, in the clearest sign yet that the central bank will not raise interest rates next month.
In its so-called Beige Book summary of economic activity, the Fed said there were signs of a slowdown in several regions and that only scattered wage or price pressures were evident.
The report reinforced the growing view that the central bank's policy-making Federal Open Market Committee will hold rates steady at its meeting July 1-2.
"The bottom line here is that the economic picture is unfolding exactly how the FOMC would like to see it," said economist Sung Won Sohn of Norwest Corp. in Minneapolis.
"Consequently, there is little chance the Fed is going to hike interest rates in July," Sohn said.

Fed policy-makers will use the Beige Book findings when they meet to weigh their next move on rates in two weeks. The Fed held short-term rates steady last month after raising them a quarter point in March, the first increase in more than two years, in a bid to slow growth and ward off inflation.
Unlike the last Beige Book report May 7 that said the economy "continued to expand," the latest report was peppered with references to a slowdown.
"Consumer spending was weaker ... with several districts reporting slower growth in retail and auto sales," it said.

Manufacturing was brisk and growing in many regions "but there were some areas of weakening." Construction and real estate were generally strong "but some districts reported pockets of weak growth," said the report, prepared by the Dallas Fed bank based on interviews conducted before June 9.
Despite shortages of professional and blue-collar workers, most districts reported "little or no wage pressure or noted that pressures were confined to a few markets," the Fed said.
Similarly, while prices for energy and for some metals used in manufacturing were rising, there was little upward pressure on prices of finished goods.
The Fed said "retail and manufacturing prices were being held in check by heavy competition, which was stimulating continued cost reduction or productivity increases."
Norwest's Sohn said it was unusual that the lowest unemployment since November 1973 was not spurring wage inflation driven by demands for higher pay.

The economy grew at a brisk 5.8 percent annual rate in the first quarter, the strongest growth in nine years, largely on a surge in consumer spending. But recent data have pointed to a slowdown in the current quarter.
Still, the economy remains relatively strong after more than six years of growth. The Fed summary said manufacturers in several regions said they were producing nearly flat out in May.

Steel producers in the Chicago area said their capacity use remained "very high," the Fed said. Plants were being expanded in the Atlanta region while executives in Dallas and St. Louis said demand was rising for construction goods.
